newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Hyundai hopes to win Vietnam licence soon.
newsitem.headline: Hyundai hopes to win Vietnam licence soon.

text.p: South Korea's largest carmaker Hyundai Motor Co expects to finally win approval to build a joint venture plant in Vietnam in the first half of this year, a company spokesman said on Thursday.

"The possibility to get the licence in the first half is much over 50 percent from an earlier 50-50 percent chance," said spokesman Min Kyong-hwan. "The Vietnamese government is starting to favour Hyundai."

Hyundai Motor, a flagship affiliate of South Korea's largest conglomerate Hyundai Group, said it would invest about $220 million in the joint venture plant, in which the company is expected to hold a 65 percent stake.
The plant, which will be located near Ho Chi Minh City, will be able to make 10,000 vehicles a year.

If Hyundai wins the licence, Min said Hyundai would boost local production of auto components by extending technical tie-ups. Korean autoparts manufacturers are expected to enter the new market with Hyundai.
Hyundai was supposed to become the 15th foreign carmaker to be licensed in Vietnam by the end of 1996.
However, Vietnam's Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet has opposed Hyundai's southern Vietnam project, arguing that the 14 foreign joint ventures already licensed were enough for the time being.

But Hyundai Motor now believes it will win a licence after Deputy Minister for Industry Nguyen Xuan Chuan said this week the Korean company would stand "a better chance" of seeing its application approved if Chrysler Corp abandoned the country's crowded market.
Local media in Vietnam have reported that Chrysler has abandoned its plans for a $192-million factory near Ho Chi Minh City, because Vietnam has licensed too many foreign carmakers.
The U.S. car giant has until July to take up a construction licence which it was granted two years ago. It has not yet officially declared whether it would walk away.
Seven ventures are already producing cars in Vietnam, and Ford Motor Co of the United States is planning to roll out its first vehicle from a $102-million plant near Hanoi this year.
Min said Hyundai would be able to compete with other foreign carmakers on price despite its late arrival in Vietnam.

"Initially, we are targeting buyers who can only afford low-priced passenger cars such as the sub-compact Accent," he said. "We will go there with commercial vehicles well-suited for narrow and poor roads."
Some 37,000 vehicles of all types were sold in Vietnam last year and cars accounted for 35 percent of the total.
"Vietnam will be an important production site for us to advance into Indochina. In addition to saving labour and transportation costs, we are able to secure a foothold in the region," Min said.
Like other South Korean carmakers seeking to diversify their export markets, Hyundai has been expanding overseas production.
The first sub-compact Accent and van Grace will roll out from a Turkey joint venture in July. Hyundai invested $22.5 million in the plant, which has an annual production capacity of 50,000 vehicles.
Hyundai spent $1.1 billion on its wholly-owned Hyundai Motor India to produce 200,000 Accents. Production is expected to start from August, 1998.
Another joint venture assembly line for 1.5-tonne trucks is under construction in Malaysia with production also expected to begin in August next year.
